H0.text: Hydrocarbons are the simplest organic compounds.

H1.text: Amino acids are the simplest organic compounds.

H2.text: Carbohydrates are the simplest organic compounds.

H3.text: Nucleotides are the simplest organic compounds.

A4.text: In organic chemistry, a hydrocarbon is an organic compound consisting entirely of hydrogen and carbon.

A5.text: Hydrocarbons can be polymers (such as polyethylene and polystyrene).

A6.text: The alkanes range in complexity from the simplest case of methane (CH4), where n = 1 (sometimes called the parent molecule), to arbitrarily large and complex molecules.

A7.text: The number of possible isomers increases rapidly with the number of carbon atoms.

A8.text: Methane (US:  METH-ayn, UK:  MEE-thayn) is a chemical compound with the chemical formula CH4 (one carbon atom bonded to four hydrogen atoms).

A9.text: Methane is an organic hydrocarbon, and among the simplest of organic compounds.
